body_html:
Thanks for taking a look! Producing the Docker image is not a problem and I
can successfully get libtensorflow_cc.so built and headers all in place.

When I build and link against them to use the Session API in my Bazel-built
project, however, I get the linker error from a cc_binary target that
relies on a cc_library target the links against libtensorflow_cc.so.

On Mon, Oct 24, 2016 at 7:21 PM drpngx notifications@github.com wrote:

So, I followed the steps (except that I used openjdk) and it worked for
me. It built using gcc, though, as it should from the Dockerfile. But your
error points to clang-3.6.

(Note that if you want to use ccache, you have to use -v :/root/.ccache
and create a gcc, g++ script.)

—
You are receiving this because you authored the thread.
Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
#5179 (comment),
or mute the thread
https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AVSu8zGABfz_jrVnwCBgui8BW1fodmI_ks5q3WeXgaJpZM4Kfbsj
.

body:
Thanks for taking a look! Producing the Docker image is not a problem and I
can successfully get libtensorflow_cc.so built and headers all in place.

When I build and link against them to use the Session API in my Bazel-built
project, however, I get the linker error from a cc_binary target that
relies on a cc_library target the links against libtensorflow_cc.so.

On Mon, Oct 24, 2016 at 7:21 PM drpngx notifications@github.com wrote:

> So, I followed the steps (except that I used openjdk) and it worked for
> me. It built using gcc, though, as it should from the Dockerfile. But your
> error points to clang-3.6.
> 
> (Note that if you want to use ccache, you have to use -v :/root/.ccache
> and create a gcc, g++ script.)
> 
> —
> You are receiving this because you authored the thread.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/issues/5179#issuecomment-255918068,
> or mute the thread
> https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AVSu8zGABfz_jrVnwCBgui8BW1fodmI_ks5q3WeXgaJpZM4Kfbsj
> .
